byline.original: By TIM ARANGO and CEYLAN YEGINSU

abstract: Many Turks view Prime Min Recep Tayyip Erdogan's resumption of military actions against Kurdistan Workers' Party as bid to regain support for his Islamist-rooted Justice and Development Party in wake of elections that left it without Parliament majority; lending credence to idea is Erdogan's stalling on forming coalition government, which is likely to lead to new elections; although fight has been framed as part of country's broader effort to combat terrorists, including Islamic State, most military operations have been directed at PKK.
lead_paragraph: Analysts say that by resuming military operations against the Kurds, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan is setting the stage for snap elections so his party can regain control of Parliament.

headline.main: Turkey’s Push Into War Is Seen as Erdogan’s Political Strategy
headline.print_headline: Trace of Turkish Politics in Clashes With Kurds

snippet: Analysts say that by resuming military operations against the Kurds, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan is setting the stage for snap elections so his party can regain control of Parliament.

keywords.value: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
